I didn't know about the photic effect until I was 40. My new/first wife told me about it. I spent 40 years not knowing how to finish off those annoying half-sneezes you can sometimes get. Now I know. I don't normally sneeze in relation to the sun, but if I am half-way to sneezing, the photic effect can help me get it out. What sucks is when there is no bright light around to help. Cloudy day? SOL. Edison-style light bulbs? Not likely, not even up close. A small reflection of the sun on a living room picture room, right when I can't get a sneeze out? Amazingly helpful. The light need not be big, just intense.

I think the only reason why this has survived as a stable gene for so long is because a sneeze is a sort of like wakeup-call which we inherited from our caveman ancestors, much like how the Yawn triggers yawning in others,

When you've been in a dark cave for long period, and suddenly come into the bright light, your brain might not be fully awake, so it triggers a sneeze which not only wakes you up, but also puts you into high-alert, because you've just made a loud sound and your caveman brain be like "Oh, need to be careful now, something could be following that sound"

My thoughts on how it works...
When you squint (going from a dark to bright area), that contracts muscles in you eyes and nasal cavity. Since you continue to breathe at the same volumetric rate, the particulate in the air breathed in through the nose will travel faster as it goes through the nose (this is a nozzeling affect, due to the more constricted nasal passage). With this higher velocity, the particulate will travel further into the nasal cavity and irritate tissue that doesn't usual see that particulate, thus triggering the sneeze.

That's it.

I've always thought (I haven't finished watching {1:48}) that it was due to a collective constriction of facial muscles that was a result of experiencing direct high intensity light the the entirety of the face area; the reflex forces you to turn your face away and into the shade, so that you can then see the immediate environment clearer and give you more time to readjust the aperture of your eyes to the change in light balance.

It may have a slight evolutionary advantage in certain particular circumstances, but not in all.

I only do it when confronted by a significant change in ambient light intensity (yes, I used to be concerned by this; I monitored every time it happened to me over about a decade {data now lost due to de-cluttering}), so I'm not sure that it is as detrimental to being a fighter pilot as you have claimed since they are most likely to experience it upon lake off and leveling than in combat (this is very much "In my imagined understanding of the situation", generally 'IMO,' since I've never been a pilot; if you are feel free to correct me).

Just to clarify, at 4:42 did you say over-stimulation of optic nerve spills over to trigeminal nerve? I must've been a slip of tongue I guess. You must've meant the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve. The optic nerve is a very well sheathed (myelinated) nerve and the chance of an over-stimulation spill over is remote. Sneezing is autonomic (Sympathetic) phenomenon, mediated by the medulla.
Reference
J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2006 Apr; 77(4): 559–561.
Published online 2005 Dec 14. doi: 10.1136/jnnp.2005.068601

That anatomy was wrong. Big way wrong. Ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve) is not at all connected to optic nerve (2nd cranial nerve). Ophthalmic branch is concerned about general sensation ( touch,pain etc). Optic nerve is concerned about the visual sensation. So, if you are suggesting ophthalmic branch somehow sensed light, it might single handedly tip the dual nature of light towards particle!

Even if now weakened I’m guessing a similar (but not equal) very old adaptation: you sneezed when waking up in the morning when they sun shone on you to clear your nose of whatever mucus and dirt that cumulated there during sleep time. Even nowadays the change in position when waking up from a prolong sleep provokes the discharge of some mucosity (generally down the throat) from the sinuses. The human species is also quite complex (and complicated) when it comes to the sinuses, nose and throat infections, thus it wouldn’t be strange that this may have been part of the process that allowed us to ride the wave a little better.
The fact that it not that prevalent nowadays may be paired with the fact that it is been quite a long time since we simply reacted as instinct-related animals: we dig our noses (yeah, shocking isn't it, but that's normal) and consciously clear our noses and throats without needing a reflex, what makes such gene somehow redundant.

Had to think about this for myself for a while long before this post.  My idea of evolutionary benefit is related to where many of our ancestors lived, in dark and moist environment.  In that kind of environment we are susceptible to breath and spores and sneezing them out when going in the sun insure a daily cleaning of spore filled mucus... daily.  Today, it is still a good thing for houses as much hermetic as we can make them with a lot of molds developping inside.

FYI, one of my former professors Stephen J. Peroutka M.D., first described this back in the late 1980s. He had this photic sneeze reflex his entire life but thought nothing of it, until he was taking his first born home from the hospital. When he went outside the hospital with his newborn, they both sneezed simultaneously going from dark to light, but his wife didn't. Hence he immediately realized that this was an autosomally dominant trait. He wanted to call it the Peroutka reflex when he published the scientific letter about it, but more sensible people intervened. Also his daughter became the youngest published author on a scientific paper, all of 3 months old when she got published.

Hi !! The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve does not transmit information about light. That is, if after being in the dark, you go out and look towards the sun, then all the excitation of the sensory cells of the retina will pass through the optic nerve, and this is another pair. Therefore, I'm not sure that the trigeminal nerve is excited at this moment. In general,  I think it is hypothesis not near verity and i think it possible to find literature that answers this question, maybe in other languages.

That all studied sun-sneezers have the T instead of a C in their DNA, does not explain their sneezing. If you want to find a relation, it can always be found, as long as you have enough variables. Considering the single nucleotides as variables, it is no surprise to find a correlation. DNA consists of this huge number of nucleotides, so you have a huge number of variables. A correlation between whether people eat breakfast or not and a random single nucleotide does probably also exist, within a studied sample, even though it makes no sense: single nucleotides do not cause people to have breakfast. So, this single nucleotide is just a coincidental correlation with the sun sneezers.

-- Sneezing is an allergic reaction.
-- Cell apoptosis is an allergic reaction.
-- Cancer is a malfunction of cell apoptosis
-- UV radiation is carcinogenic

Hypothesis:

-- Sun sneezing is an evolutionary trait that triggers cell apoptosis via some unspecified sympathetic relationship in the body, in response to damaging radiation from the sun.

This is not a valid conclusion, without an additional premise that links cell apoptosis to sneezing. (Undistributed Middle Term Violation) However, it would suggest some measure of correlation if humans that were more genetically susceptible to damaging UV radiation were statistically more likely to carry the sun sneezing gene.

If you're about to sneeze and you need to prevent that (e.g. at an important meeting, or while driving in city traffic), try pushing your nose bridge or your upper lip with a finger. Wait, it affects 1 in 4 people, and the mutation responsible is a nucleotide swap of a C instead of T; meanwhile there are 4 possible bases A, C, G, and T. So it looks like either 1: there might be a significant enough number of people with the other two bases instead of a C or T and this is a neutral mutation, or 2: these two variants are dominant in the population and sun sneezers are less favored over non-sun sneezers.

Sure, if a change like this happened today, it wouldn't spread very widely. But if it happened when human population was rather small, being a meaningless advantage, it's not abnormal that it ended up in that small part of today's population.

Genes are usually activated in bundles, so a photic sneeze reflex doesn't need an evolutionary benefit - but if a sun sneezing comes with a gene network that has other advantages, it's easy for it to survive. The easiest way to see the fact that genes are activated in clusters is probably the study on taming foxes that was done not too long ago. And they managed to make them tame in a very short timespan (I think it was about 30 generations). These foxes had a much more soft fur and wagged their tail among other traits - in other words - they were suddenly much like dogs. And this change wouldn't be possible without clusters. IMPORTANT THEORY! I am a sun sneezer and I have always hypothesized that these sneezes have a protective purpose by forcing your eyes to close when looking at the bright light. The eyes close for two reasons, first to protect the retina from light damage before your eyes have accommodated to the increase light. Secondly, to allow time for this accommodation so by the time you reopen your eyes the lens of your eyes have adjusted and you can see well in the bright environment.

I wouldn't be so quick to dismiss this trait as something that came about through evolution simply because not all people exhibit it. If it was an advantageous trait in a certain population living in a certain area, but not advantageous to all people living in all places, you would expect to see the trait disseminated throughout the global population many generations after the population for whom the trait was advantageous was intermixed with other groups. If it had simply been a random mutation that offered no advantage to anyone at any time, it would likely not be as prevalent as it is today.

Sneezing raises dopamine, coordinates your system, tightens your muscles, clears up your nose. Why wouldn't the body want that first thing in the morning or when coming to the outside? In fact, it seems very implausible that viruses evolved us to sneeze to benefit themselves, its more likely that they hack a preexisting reflex to their advantage. Viruses can make permanent changes to DNA even passed down to offspring, the fact that there is a minority of humans that sneeze due to sunlight may indicate that the more prone to sneeze a person was, the higher the risk of death by virus was in the population. Those who have the sneezing gene are the ones whose ancestors survived the viruses despite their propensity to sneeze and their DNA has not been corrupted to eliminate this reflex.

I also have the photic sneeze reflex. I sneeze even if my eyes are closed, and I noticed that in all of your video-recorded sneezes your eyes were either closed or nearly closed. Therefore I don't think that retinal stimulation causes this reflex. I also noticed that my sneezes are strongest when sunlight is strongly reflecting from the ground, especially if it is nearly white concrete. Olfactory chemoreceptors are very similar to retinal photoreceptors, so I suspect that when bright light enters the nose it can non-specifically stimulate the olfactory epithelial cells, to which a sneeze reflex would be an appropriate response. Perhaps this gene only affects how easily light can reach the olfactory cells?

For those who are interested, I thought I might clarify what Derek was talking about with regard to that single letter change (called a Single Nucleotide Polymorphism, or SNP - pronounced 'snip') which is associated with those who are sun sneezers. What the study showed was that an somebody who has that SNP is more likely to be a sun sneezer than somebody who does not. This doesn't imply that the SNP has any functional importance in the photic sneeze reflex. The way in which these studies work is that they sequence the DNA of the participants and compare the changes which come up more often than you would expect by chance in the sun sneezers' DNA vs non-sun sneezers' DNA. Unfortunately, sequencing the entire genome of a person is not cheap. Instead, what the researchers do is they look very specifically only for these SNPs. SNPs, like many mutations, arise purely by chance and the vast majority of the time don't have any harmful effects at all. The reason they are useful to a geneticist is because they are scattered throughout everybody's DNA and act like little markers of inheritance. This is because, if they are sitting right next to a gene, then most of the time they get carried with the gene when you inherit it from your parents. So, if for instance you have brown eyes, there will be little SNPs which get carried around with the brown eyes genes when you inherit them. So the way in which companies like 23andMe know what colour your eyes are is because they look for SNPs in your DNA which are known to be passengers near genes which give you brown eyes, or blue eyes etc. The SNP which Derek talks about in the video is, therefore, a passenger to the genes which make you a sun-sneezer but isn't what makes you a sun-sneezer - you're just far more likely to have it if you are. The sequencing that the study did would not actually be able to find the changes in the gene which make you a sun-sneezer because it only looks for single letter changes. I hope that is clear. If anybody has any questions, I would be very happy to answer them as best as I can. I am a 3rd year geneticist at the University of Cambridge and so genetics is my passion.

3:16 "I don't think this gives a genetic advantage otherwise everyone would have it."
I don't think that would need to be the case. A genetic trade can survive even if it is little or just works in some situations. Neither is the argument "otherwise everyone would have it" strong enough.
A trade could give enough advantages in places where that really is an advantage and therefor it would survive there. But it might also have disadvantages. For example it could be dangerous/disadvantageous for people to warn their surroundings of leaving the cave. Therefor there would be a balance as where the advantages would way against the disadvantages, which would explain why it occurs only in a percentage of the population. Also it could have been an advantage in old times but not have enough disadvantages to already be routed out of our genes in current times. This will also dilute the presence of a gene but not make it completely disappear.

My theory about sneezing when exposed to bright light goes like this :)
It is impossible to have your eyes open while sneezing, this is well known and probably to protect the eyes somehow. When exposed to sudden bright light we reflexively close our eyes, for obvious reasons. And, whenever the nervous system does something automatically there are neural pathways going both ways, there are many many examples of this. My theory is that when we are exposed to bright sunlight an automatic response to shut our eyes are triggered (whether we shut them or not) and this ups the signal for sneezing. Just a pet theory, entirely based on 'makes sense', 'sounds reasonable' ie Aristoteles style. ;)

Your theory doesn't work for me, my sneezing also occurs in darkness.  I usually sneeze three times.  Sometimes I sneeze when I walk out into the Sun, but I will also sneeze when I walk into a room with a different smell, like perfume, or when someone wearing perfume passes by me.  I sneeze when I walk into a house I haven't been in before, with a different aroma - like old persons houses.  I sneeze when I walk into a kitchen and something is cooking.  I sneeze when a light breeze hits my nose at a certain angle.   
The sneezes can  be avoided If I take certain steps.  For example, if I hold my head down and walk into the Sun at a certain angle I won't sneeze.  Its usually when I drop my guard that I sneeze.  Nevertheless, I sneeze 15-40 times a day.  You get used to it.  Its always the same pattern - 1/2-2 seconds notice, then bam-bam--bam.

I was a bit dissappointed with the anatomical explanation presented here:

The optic nerve (not the opthalmic branch of the Trigeminal) is the one that reacts to the sensation of light on the retina.
The way I understand it, you should have included that in your explanation and then proceed to explain how the Optic nerve can trigger a reaction in the opthalmic branch of the Trigeminal nerve, which would then proceed to "cross-over" or be misinterpreted by the brain as an itchy feeling in the nose.
I can't really explain how this happens, but I suppose that since the Optic nerve causes a reflex reaction to light it might start a chain reaction of nerve stimulation that might end up causing the opthalmic branch to send a sensory signal that eventually causes sneezing.

The one nucleotide mutation is called a single nucleotide polymorphism, or an SNP (polymorphism as in a unique variant in that certain region of DNA). The SNP is likely not the causative agent of this trait, but rather a marker allele that is close enough in sequence to the causative mutation and is thus inherited with every copy of the sneeze allele. In simpler terms, the SNP he refers to isn't causing the change, it's likely just a marker for it.

Getting a 23andme test might not always be the brightest idea, especially without a physicain or geneticist to help you interpret results. My man ZDOGGMD covers that in one of his recent episdoes. I wish you mentioned that Veritasium, especially since some may misunderstand or abuse their results!

Edit: (why)

Some tests results are obvious and easy to understand. For other genetic markers. The results have some problems.

For example, if you happen to have a gene with low penetrance and no family history, the test will be more confusing that helpful.

Or if one of my anxiety patients decided to open this up and have a 10% extra chance of getting a blood clot, they will completely FREAK OUT.

Or if it says you have a low risk for diabetes, some patients will abuse that and say "low risk, I can eat as much as I want".

Genetics are not at all as simple as anyone thinks and every year even geneticists are stumped by new results. Epigentics means you may have certain genes that are methylated and turned OFF or ON based on your lifestyle and the lifestyle of your mother and grandmother. If you want to order this, you might consider a methylation study.

What about people from a population where their genes haven't been adequately sequenced (23andme is mostly Ashkenazi Jews and Caucasians). A gene might have evolved to have a completely different result in someone from Africa or Asia.

Now see, if I were to guess I'd say the sneeze was caused by the squinting action--the movement of the muscles and their effect on the surrounding areas. And I'd guess this because my nose can be... sensitive. Something bumps it just right (for instance) to cause any of the hairs inside to poke or brush against the soft tissue within, and it can easily trigger a sneeze. I've even managed to get this to happen on certain occasions by scrunching up my nose or "making faces".

And I wouldn't completely rule it out for some (perhaps rare) instances. But it appears that the common (or perhaps only) cause is simply that nerve's reaction to a sudden increase in light intensity.

The trigeminal nerve's ophthalmic branch doesn't recieve sensory information from the eye, but rather from the skin (touch) of the forehead and nose. The optic nerve is completely different from the trigeminal nerve.

The trigeminal nerve IS a sensory nerve, but I know of no reason to believe it's photosensitive (at solar power levels).  The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) is the input from the retina to the brain.  I know of three possible ways to CN II could mediate the response: 1) thalamus-cortex, 2) hypothalamus, 3) tectum.  I think the latter is the most likely.  The thalamus-cortex paths are pretty much dedicated to vision.  The retinohypothalamic circuitry is important for entraining day/night circadian rhythms.  The rectinotectal path is a phylogenetically ancient circuit for orienting head movement to light.  The superior colliculus of the tectum is responsible for the reflex movement of the head toward bright light flashes, just as the inferior colliculus mediates reflex movements due to loud noises.  (It is a reflex, irrespective of neck pain, contra the Brady Bunch.)  Because of the time course and reflex nature of the sneeze reflex, my bet would be that sudden changes from dark to bright light triggers a tectal-brainstem cascade that eventually causes a sneeze.  Whether it has evolutionary significance or is just an epiphenomenon of wiring is speculation.  A second, less likely IMHO opinion, possibility would be cross-talk between the LGN and somatosensory areas of the thalamus (which would account for the tickling sensation).  Either way, I doubt the trigeminal (CN V) has anything to do with it.

I'm curious how 23 and Me does that analysis. I mean, first, how do they isolate your cells and ultimately your DNA from your saliva. There are bound to be other cells in there, particularly bacteria. So, it's not just finding any cell. It has to be a human cell. And then what do they do from there?

Frequently, features that aren't in any way helpful for the survival of an animal can appear through mutation (a.k.a. evolve) and remain in the gene pool. So while sun-sneezing being in some way helpful towards the survival of our ancestors can be a possible explanation for it remaining in our gene pool, it's in no way the only possible explanation. It can seem counter-intuitive.

I'd recommend Richard Dawkin's The Selfish Gene for more info on that. It's a fun read.

Hey Veritasium!

Just a clarification- the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) is the nerve responsible for transmitting information from the retina to the visual cortex in the back of the brain. The ophthalmic nerve (first branch of the trigeminal nerve, cranial nerve 5) is a nerve that- like you said- receives sensory information from the upper face. However, these are two very different nerves- if light were to stimulate the maxillary branch, it would have to do so through the brain itself :)

I don't think this cave theory makes much sense. Your sneeze reflex is normally intended to expel potentially-harmful irritants from your respiratory system before they can cause further harm. Viruses and bacteria hijack this so that they can use the symptom to spread themselves, but there is no personal benefit to sneezing later without any provocation and the normal reflex obviously exists for a survival reason. Instead, what I see is that it WAS provoked. The reaction of your un-adjusted eyes to sudden bright sunlight exposure is much the same as they would react to an airborne irritant. The primary difference is that an airborne irritant would usually also be detected by your nose which would probably also get irritated. Think about the advantages we get from having neurons that fire together, wire together. These two reactions so often go hand-in-hand that one could serve as an early-warning system for the other, possibly saving the life of someone who sneezes when their eyes are irritated even without involving the sinuses. I imagine some ancient spore that was deadly once inhaled in human lungs but only an irritant in human eyes. If the eyes triggered a sneeze, there's a better chance that the sneeze reflex would clear your respiratory system of the spore and give you warning that there is something dangerous here ("back away!").

I can't believe nobody's pointed out the possibility of it being a psychosomatic response. It's the type of effect where, if somebody's allergic to peanuts, and you tell them (dishonestly) that something they just ate had peanuts in it, it can cause their throat to swell closed anyway.

If someone is horribly allergic to flowers, just seeing a flower can invoke the response. Even merely seeing a picture of a flower, which surely doesn't have anything on it to cause such a reaction, can still cause them to itch. Their body makes a correlation, and reacts even when it doesn't have to.

People have lived indoors for tens of thousands of years. We've always constructed shelters to keep the wind off us, which also kept out dust and pollen. When you step outside, from a dim place indoors into the bright outdoors, you expose yourself to a whole bunch of wind, dust, and pollen that you hadn't been experiencing a second ago. Your body makes a correlation (dim=indoors=no allergens, bright=outdoors=many allergens flying in your face), and reacts psychosomatically, even when it doesn't have to.

I'd be curious to see if the gene linked to sun-sneezing is more generally linked to being susceptible to psychosomatic reactions in general.

Actually, the real name of this condition is the Photo-Achoo-stic Effect.

The problem is the opthalmic nerve and the optic nerve are different nerves. Opthalmic - innervates the skin around the eye and the eyeball. Optic nerve - carries the signal from the photoreceptors. So stimulation of the II cranial (flash of light) is carried in completelly different way than stimuli from V2 which may be interpreted as nose itching.

Population-protective genes need not be individual-protective genes! Population genetics may (often does) prefer diverse genetics rather than one preponderant genetics! Immunity, famously, protects not only immune individuals but also protects susceptible individuals by removing some of the contagion vector --- but on the other hand, immunity is expensive (part of why getting sick makes you tired) and tends to specialize --- your system can only learn to recognize just-so many threats; so, letting different individuals be immune to different rare diseases can be better, poplation-survivalwise than everyone being immune to the same bunch of things.
